Pharen: Lisp -> PHP

  • Introduction
  • Downloading and usage
  • Pharen Basics
  • Lists and Dictionaries

Lists and Dictionaries

List Literals

A list is just a collection of values of any type. They are equivalent to arrays in PHP that don’t have keys explicitly set by the programmer. When creating lists, separate each item with a space and enclose everything in square brackets.

; The numbers from 1 to 7
[1 2 "three" "four" 5]

; A list of strings
["foo" "bar" "baz"]

; Lists can be nested in each other
[[1 2] ["abc" "def"]]

<?php
array(1, 2, "three", "four", 5);
 

array("foo", "bar", "baz");

 
array(array(1, 2), array("abc", "def"));
?>

Dictionaries

Dictionaries are created using the dict keyword, followed by key-value pairs enclosed in parentheses. They are the equivalent to associative arrays where keys are explicitly set. Keys can be either integers or strings and values can be any Pharen expression.

(dict
    ("title" "Color of Magic")
    ("author" "Terry Pratchett"))

(dict
    ("functional" ["haskell" "lisp" "scala"])
    ("imperative" ["c" "php" "python"]))

<?php
array(
    "title" => "Color of Magic",
    "author" => "Terry Pratchett"
);

array(
    "functional" => array("haskell", "lisp", "scala"),
    "imperative" => array("c", "php", "python")
);
?>

Retrieving elements

To get values back from a dictionary or list, prepend the variable’s name with a colon and use it as if it was a function:

(define user (dict
	("name" "Arthur Dent")
	("location" "
